subject: Re: Methods that does not return value
msgSnippet: Rick, The reason why I want inVAJava() to return true, is so that JUnit will be able to run tests. (My own tests) When inVAJava() returns false or throws
messageBody:
Rick,

The reason why I want inVAJava() to return true, is so that
JUnit will be able to run tests. (My own tests) When inVAJava()
returns false or throws exception, the tests will not run.

How do I know this? Well, I tried changing the inVAJava() method to
return true and false.

Thanks,

Lily.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Rick Berman <rick.berman@a...> wrote:
> Throwing a class not found exception, catching it, and
> then returning false is correct behavior for the
> method inVAJava(). The class isn't found because you
> aren't running inside of VAJ.
>
> You still haven't answered why you *want* inVAJava()
> to return true when you aren't inside the VAJ
> environment. Once we know that, then perhaps we can
> get closer to addressing your issue.
>
> Rick
>
> --- ok_lilya <lilya.jangirov@r...> wrote:
> > Rick,
> >
> > I tried leaving out com.ibm.uvm.tools.DebugSupport
> > from classpath but
> > then what happens, it throws a class not found
> > exception and still
> > doesn't return true.
> >
> > Thanks,
> >
> > Lily.
